<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_destroy:
```c
void
MHD_pool_destroy (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  if (NULL == pool)
    return;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
  if (! pool->is_mmap)
    free (pool->memory);
  else
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && ! defined(_WIN32)
    munmap (pool->memory,
            pool->size);
#elif defined(_WIN32)
    VirtualFree (pool->memory,
                 0,
                 MEM_RELEASE);
#else
    abort ();
#endif
  free (pool);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The controlling expression in the mhd_assert depends on the runtime value pool->pos (it compares pool->pos with ROUND_TO_ALIGN(pool->pos)), so it is not an invariant constant expression. This is a runtime consistency check, not a constant controlling expression. (Only if ROUND_TO_ALIGN were somehow a compile-time constant independent of pool->pos would the expression be invariant and thus violate the rule.)
